//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. There is a connectivity issue between Customer-1 and Customer-2. File servers between the customers cannot send critical data. R3 routes are missing from the routing table on the Customer-1 router. All interfaces on Customer-1 are up. Which configuration must be applied to router R2 to correct the problem?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Yes it's A
Router 1 L0 1.2.2.2/32 IP is overlapping with the 1.1.1.0/24 on the Router 2 - Router 3 link.

Selected Answer: A
The only choice that makes sense is A. By default, IS-IS protocol leaks routing information from a Level 1 area to a Level 2 area. The only thing that would prevent L1 routes from being leaked into level 2 is if IS-IS is not configured/activated on Router 1.

comments.content: This doesn't make sense to me, as why would they say the issue is specifically "Level 1 routes are not being converted to Level 2 routes" If they aren't activated, they wouldn't even be Level 1 routes I would think

choices.C: On Router 1, summarize internal routes between areas.
choices.D: On Router 2, summarize internal routes between areas.

choices.A: On Router 1, redistribute the routes into IGP.

Refer to the exhibit. A network engineer configured three new PE routers to expand the network. The new routers run the IS-IS routing protocol and reside in the data center in the same exchange as the existing routers. However, the network is now experiencing suboptimal routing. The Layer 2 configuration and VLANs are configured correctly to provide segregation between networks, but the Level 1 routes are not being converted to Level 2 routes. Which action resolves the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct

choices.A: Add a second filtering policy in the format ip access-list 1 permit ^152_([0-9]+).
choices.D: Change the filtering policy to ip as-path access-list 1 permit _152_.
choices.C: Change the filtering policy to ip explicit-path 1 permit $152^.
choices.B: Add a second filtering policy in the format ip prefix-list 1 permit ^152^.

I have to suppose that this lab is answered correctly, so I guess I'm going to use the p2p commands

OSPF will always advertise the networks on loopback interfaces as /32 networks, even if you have configured them with a different subnet. This is how OSPF operates, and it is even defined within the RFC. If you want to change this behavior, you can use the ip ospf network point-to-point command under the loopback interface configuration mode. This will cause OSPF to advertise the configured subnet mask of the loopback interface.
